Title: N/A

reviewText: I am a fan of History, documentaries, & of weaponry. So this title offered a neat little package of what I like. What I got isn't horrible, but it does disappoint on a few levels.On the good side, the documentaries are informative & provides straight forward facts about the development of firearms, broken down into seven episodes focusing on major events of American History. It offers up clear definition footage of many of the guns instead of relying on the sole use of grainy stock footage.On the bad side, with the exception of the first episode, the overall focus is quite heavy on the American influence & lineage of firearm history. That's not to say it totally ignores the achievements of other nations. But they seem to treat them more as footnotes rather than vital steps in an evolutionary process. All in all, I couldn't shake the feeling that this was more of a NRA vehicle rather than an educational tool.In short, not a bad purchase if you can get it cheap. But even as a fan of the genre, I wouldn't consider this a "must have".
summary: Not Bad for an NRA Ad.

reviewText: There was a clear and consistent effort to be as accurate and authentic as possible in the creation of this DVD series. The historical recreations are intense, layered and detailed with great care in the special effects and historical truth and authenticity along with the powerful voice of narrator Coby Batty and other voice actors help to bring these stories of how firearms have been used and developed (thru use in war and the military) to life for a mass audience - from ancient chinese invention of gunpowder thru the middle ages and the new world, to the American Revolution onto the Civil War, WW1 and WW2... Vietnam era to the invention of the two biggest weapons of our day -- the AK-47 and the M-16... to today's War in Iraq and Afghanistan.  Three historical experts comment during all 7 parts of the series.
summary: Great care was taken to keep the visuals authentic and accurate
Title: N/A

reviewText: This program is well-made and quite interesting, particularly its five first episodes which cover the period through World War I.  Unfortunately, the last two episodes which deal with World War II and the modern era are far too centered on American guns to the exclusion of almost all others.  While it's understandable that, because of the ever expanding variety in types of guns, a progressively greater selection must be exercized to remain within the duration of the hourly episodes, this does not explain why precious minutes should be liberally expanded in the anecdotal description of the combat performance of certain weapons while other important types of guns are completely ignored.  For example Episode 6 which covers World War II provides a (far too) lengthy description of the combat performance of the M-1 Garand, but does not even mention such ground-breaking weapons as the British Sten and German MP38/40 from which modern submachine guns are derived, or the the German Sturmgewher 44 which is the ancestor of all assault rifles, or the German MG38 and MG42 which are the inspiration of all modern all-purpose machine guns.  Episode 7 is even more American-centered and is almost exclusively dedicated to the M-16 and its follow-up M-4 with only a token mention of the AK-47 Kalashnikov.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I picked up this 2-disc set at a bargain price.  Since I have been into guns most of my life, having had to carry one for thirty years, and also being a range instructor for my agency,  I thought this would be an interesting DVD set.  I was not disappointed.  I have had a life-long love of history, whether it be about American History, Martial Arts history or weapons history.  Those people who hate guns just never seem to grasp the fact that throughout history guns have played an important and vital part of our culture.This excellent 7-part series covers an enormous amount of material.  The first episode explains the invention of gun powder to the American rifle.  The second part deals with the Flintlock to the percussion cap. The third part focuses on the weapons of the civil war. The fourth part tells about post civil war weapons and the winning of the west. The fifth part covers the weapons of World War 1. The weapons of World War 2 is explained in episode 7.  The final episode covers post world war 2 to today, from the M-14 to the M4 Carbine.  These 7-part series run approximately 4 hours and 33 minutes.If you have a passion for firearms you should check out this series.  Personally, I learned a lot of information about guns that I was unaware of until viewing this series.Rating: 5 Stars.  Joseph J. Truncale  (Author:  Use of the Monadnock Straight Baton(MEB) )
summary: An excellent 7-part documentary series on guns.  Well worth the price.  If you are into guns, check out this 2-disc set.
